sen.j: 佐々木 高綱（ささき たかつな）は、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の武将。
sen.e: Takatsuna SASAKI was busho (Japanese military commander) from the end of Heian period to the early Kamakura period.
Takatsuna SASAKI was a busho (Japanese military commander) from the end of Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 近江国の佐々木庄を地盤とする佐々木氏の棟梁である佐々木秀義の四男として生まれ、平安京に住んでいたとされる。
sen.e: He was born as the forth son of Hideyoshi SASAKI, who was toryo (head of the clan) of the Sasaki clan having Sasakinosho of Omi Province electoral regional base, and lived in Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

He was born as the fourth son of Hideyoshi SASAKI, who was toryo (head of the clan) of the Sasaki clan, based on Sasaki no sho Manor in Omi Province, and lived in Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

sen.j: 『平家物語』や『源平盛衰記』にその活躍が描かれ、宇治川の戦いにおける梶原景季との先陣争いで知られる。
sen.e: His activities were depicted in "Heike Monogatari"(The Tale of the Heike) and "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans), and he was known for the battle to get spearhead against Kagesue KAJIWARA on the Battle of Uji-gawa River.

sen.j: 歌舞伎の『鎌倉三代記』にも登場し、非常に人気のある武士である。

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）に源頼朝が伊豆国で平氏打倒の兵を挙げると、兄弟の佐々木定綱、佐々木経高、佐々木盛綱と共にそれに加わって、山木兼隆を討つ。
sen.e: When MINAMOTO no Yoritomo rose in arms to defeat the Taira clan in Izu Province in 1180, he joined Yoritomo with his brothers Sadatsuna SASAKI, Tsunetaka SASAKI, and Moritsuna SASAKI and defeated Kanetaka YAMAKI.

sen.j: 石橋山の戦いでは椙山に奮戦して頼朝の危急を救った。
sen.e: He saved Yoritomo from imminent danger by fighting bravely in Sugiyama on the Battle of Ishibashiyama.

sen.j: 元暦元年（1184年）正月の源義仲追討では源義経の陣に従い、宇治川の戦いでは、頼朝に与えられた名馬「生食」にまたがって梶原景季と先陣を争った。
sen.e: When he hunted down and killed MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka in February 1184, he followed the armed camp of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and battled for spearhead against Kagesue KAJIWARA on the Battle of Uji-gawa River by riding the fine horse named 'Ikesugi' that was given by Yoritomo.

sen.e: The house of Takatsuna SASAKI was said to be near Hachiman-gu Shrine in Toriyama-cho, Kohoku-Ward, Yokohama City, and his horse 'Ikesugi' is still enshrined near there as Bato Kannon (horse-headed Kannon).
